bibl.title: Transcript of letter from James Carroll to Jennie Carroll, September 23, 1900

div1.p: Carroll informs his wife that he is recovering from yellow fever and now is comforted that he will be immune from the terrors of the disease. He also explains that Lazear is very ill and predicts an even chance for his recovery.

div1.head: Transcript of letter from James Carroll to Jennie Carroll, September 23, 1900
div1.opener:
Letter of Dr. Carroll to his wife published by Hemmeter in Janus 1908 page 164-165
Camp Columbia, Quemados, Cuba
Sunday, Sept. 23, 1900
My dear Jennie:
div1.p:
I write this to let you know that I am still alive and gaining
strength. I look forward to morrow's (sic) mail for some news from Doctor
Reed as I have not heard a word from him and do not know what to expect.
Agramonte left for New York yesterday with his wife and Doctor Lazear is
still very ill with about even chances for his recovery. Major Cartwright
who was the next to take yellow fever after me, died this morning. I asked
for an autopsy and it was refused. Doctor John Guiteras, formerly Professor
of Pathology at the University of Pa. called to see me this afternoon as also
did Dr. Gorgas and Dr. Finley (sic). Everybody is surprised at the manner in
which I am picking up flesh ad (sic) strength and all these yellow fever
experts remarked how strong I was upon my legs. Yellow fever has no terrors
for me now, because I am an immune and cannot contract it again, which gives
me a great feeling of comfort....................
